TF050007-MONTREAL PROTOCOL-THAILAND:
            BUILDING CHILLER REPLACEMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Thailand Building Chiller
            Replacement Project has a satisfactory outcome, is highly
            likely to be sustainable, and has a high institutional
            development impact. The performances of both the Bank and
            the Borrower are satisfactory. The key lessons listed were:
            1) Flexible project design needed: Despite well thought
            through technical consideration, projects of this nature
            being implemented in a very dynamic macroeconomic
            environment (e.g., economic recovery, falling interest
            rates, and increase in private savings) should have a more
            flexible design to adjust to the implementation environment.
            2) Single funding source or better blend funds needed; the
            added complexity of the administration of both funds was not
            adequately addressed at the designed stage which led to
            additional complication in project implementation and
            monitoring. 3) Providing the right information to the right
            audience: To induce a faster rate of replacement,
            information on proven energy savings, the high rate of
            return to the investment on chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) chiller
            replacement, the reduced amount of CFC import quota, and the
            continued reduction of global CFC production should be
            disseminated by the government to the top management of
            target enterprises that still have CFC chillers in
            operations. 4) Clear policy and incentive mechanism:
            Project experience has shown that unclear policy and
            competing financial subsidies could lead to the suboptimal
            outcome. 5) Refrigerant management of the recovered CFC: the
            Department of Industrial Works together with the chiller and
            refrigerant suppliers need to prepare a refrigerant
            management strategy and action plan to cope with the
            recovered CFC as more CFC chillers are being replaced. 6)
            Periodic maintenance and monitoring has resulted in low
            downtime; the operator was able to spot any operational
            irregularities and optimize the energy consumption according
            to the work environment.
